THE PROPOSAL

1.
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  Report  and  Recommendation  on  (i)  proposed
program cluster concept for the Private Sector Development Program (PSDP) in the Democratic
Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka, (ii) proposed loans to the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri
Lanka for the Private Sector Development Subprogram I, and (iii) proposed technical assistance
for Governance and Institutional Support for Private Sector Development.

II.

INTRODUCTION

2.
In  1997,  the  Government  of  Sri  Lanka  asked  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  for
assistance  with  (i)  public  enterprise  and  industry  sector  policy  reform,  and  (ii)  capital  market
development.  In  response,  ADB  fielded  a  staff  consultant  in  January  19981  and  a  follow-up
consultation  mission2  in  March  1998.  Their  findings  indicated  that  the  main  impediment  to
accelerated  growth  in  Sri  Lanka  is  the  country’s  incomplete  transition  to  a  competitive  market
system;  this  prevents  the  private  sector  from  achieving  its  full  potential.  Accordingly,  technical
assistance  (TA)3  was  prepared  to  consider  reforms  of  public  enterprises,  the  industry  sector,
and  capital  market,  to  support  the  broader  aim  of  facilitating  and  enhancing  private  sector
participation  in  economic  activity.  The  PSDP,  which  is  consistent  with  both  ADB’s  and  the
Government’s medium-term strategies, aims to eliminate impediments to more extensive private
sector  participation  in  the  economy;  create  an  enabling  environment  for  private  sector
participation,  particularly  in  infrastructure  development;  promote  market-oriented  policies;  and
foster greater reliance on the use of market mechanisms. The PSDP builds on the gains already
achieved from earlier reforms to strengthen the private sector’s role in Sri Lanka. The TA was
completed in March 2000.

3.
The  Fact-Finding  Mission  visited  Sri  Lanka  from  6  to  16  March  2000  and  with  the
Government formulated the policy reform agenda for the PSDP. The Appraisal Mission4 reached
agreement with the Government on the package of policy reforms that is to be supported by the
ADB  loans,  the  use  of  the  program  cluster  approach  for  the  PSDP,  the  program  structure,  its
subcomponents and tranching conditions, the size and terms of the ADB loans for Subprogram I
of  the  PSDP,  and  implementation  arrangements.  The  program  cluster  approach  will  provide
flexibility  for  PSDP  implementation  given  the  complexity  and  sensitiveness  of  various  reform
actions  to  be  undertaken  and  prevailing  uncertainties  owing  to  the  civil  conflict.  The
Government’s  development  policy  letter  and  the  policy  matrix  are  contained  in  appendixes  1
and 2.

The  Government  has  refocused  its  role  to  concentrate  on  areas  where  market
mechanisms do not function effectively, such as, education, health, environment, rural and small

recognizes  the  need  to  reform  social  delivery,  but  more  importantly,  to  attract  private

7.
The  Government  has  committed  to  raise  the  share  of  income  of  the  poor  from  the
current 4 percent to 15 percent by 2010. Based on latest available estimates, between one fifth
to one third of the population live below the poverty line, that is, one fifth if the lower poverty line
(least  cost  diet)  estimate  of  SLRs860  per  person  per  month  is  used,  and  one  third  using  the
higher poverty line (diet prevailing among poor households) estimated at SLRs1,032 per person
per month.7 Poverty decreased between 1985/86 and 1997 from 45 percent to 31 percent using
the higher poverty line estimate. Poverty is predominantly a rural affliction in Sri Lanka with over
85 percent of the poor situated in rural areas, working in agriculture and fisheries. Past welfare-
oriented poverty reduction strategies based mainly on handouts were replaced with employment
creation  and  income  generating  approaches  to  raise  the  income  of  low-income  families.
However, in the 1990s, little progress has been achieved in reducing poverty. The Government
recently introduced the framework for the reduction of poverty that targets to reduce poverty in
all  its  many  dimensions,  create  opportunities  for  the  poor,  strengthen  the  social  protection
system,  and  empower  the  poor.  The  framework  was  prepared  over  two  years  with  wide
participation by stakeholders, the Government, the academic community, technical experts, aid
representatives,  and  local  and  international  nongovernment  organizations.  Workshops  were
held in May 1998, February 1999, October 1999, and May 2000.

B. 

Recent Economic Performance and Prospects

8.
The Sri Lankan economy has performed creditably over the last 20 years growing at a
4.2 percent annual average rate in the 1980s, accelerating to 5.2 percent in the 1990s8 despite
periodic  droughts  and  the  long  drawn-out  civil  conflict.  After  achieving  real  gross  domestic
product  (GDP)  growth  of  4.7  percent  in  1998,  economic  growth  slackened  to  4.3  percent  in
1999,  mainly  due  to  declining  industrial  production  and  a  fall  in  exports  due  to  weak  export
markets.  After  a  slow  increase  of  3  percent  during  the  first  quarter  of  1999,  industrial
performance  accelerated  due  to  a  gradual  improvement  in  exports,  particularly  during  the  last
quarter of the year. The agriculture sector also performed well with a higher output of plantation
crops.

The  ratio  of  national  savings  to  GDP  inched  up  from  23.4  percent  to  23.9  percent  in
9.
1999  because  of  higher  private  savings  and  a  reduction  in  Government  dissavings.  However,
domestic investments reflected a larger increase from 25.1 percent to 27.1 percent chiefly due
to the upgrading of SriLankan Airlines and expansion of telecommunications services, leading to
an increase in the national savings-investment gap.

10.
The  unemployment  rate  declined  to  8.9  percent  in  1999  from  9.5  percent  the  previous
year  as  a  result  of  increased  employment  in  tourism,  strong  growth  registered  by  small
businesses,  and  higher  recruitment  by  the  public  sector.  Population  grew  at  an  annual  rate  of
1.4 percent and reached approximately 19 million by the end of 1999.

11.
The budget deficit declined from 9.2 percent in 1998 to 7.5 percent in 1999, due to a rise
in revenues and a reduction of expenditures. Government revenues rose from 17.2 percent to
17.6  percent  of  GDP  due  to  a  sizeable  improvement  in  collections  from  income  taxes,  excise
taxes, national security levy, and nontax revenue, while overall expenditures declined from 26.4
percent  of  GDP  in  1998  to  25.1  percent  in  1999.  The  Government's  defense  expenditure
averaged 3.3 percent of GDP annually during the first half of the 1990s. Following a breakdown
in negotiations on settlement of the civil conflict in 1995, defense expenditure increased to an
average  of  5.4  percent  of  GDP  during  the  second  half  of  the  1990s.  It  currently  amounts  to
about  5.1  percent  of  GDP  owing  partly  to  the  intensification  of  conflict  since  April  2000.  To
finance  the  additional  expenditure  on  war  efforts,  the  Government  has  raised  the  national
security  levy  and  excise  taxes  on  alcohol  and  tobacco,  and  reduced  nonessential  capital
expenditure  by  about  10  percent.  Monetary  policy  was  eased  as  inflation  declined.  Inflation
averaged  4.7  percent  in  1999  vis-à-vis  9.4  percent  in  1998,  due  to  the  improved  domestic
supply  of  food  items  and  lower  import  prices.  Broad  money,  comprising  currency  notes,
checking accounts, and fixed deposits, rose by 13.3 percent in 1999, and credit to the private
sector rose by 12 percent.

Background and Recent Performance

IV. 

THE SECTOR

16.
Before 1977, the Government embarked on wide-ranging program to nationalize the Sri
Lankan economy. Under the Government Business Acquisition Act, basic industries, all utilities,
and a major part of the banking system were taken over by the state. State control extended to
trade,  and  various  limitations  were  placed  on  land  and  house  ownership  and  bank  credit.
Government policy was shaped largely by overriding concerns about unemployment and by the
socialist  orientation  of  successive  public  administrations  after 
independence.  Chronic
unemployment  has  been  a  serious  problem9  and  has  been  exacerbated  by  high  population
growth.  Concerns  about  unemployment  plus  a  widening  balance  of  payments  deficit  led  to  a
bias  for  domestic  production  and  to  the  adoption  of  an  import  substituting  and  inward-looking
policy. Fears that sufficient investments in industrial projects may not be forthcoming from the
private  sector  to  absorb  new  entrants  into  the  labor  force  prompted  extensive  Government
intervention  in  commercial  activities.  With  a  diminished  role  for  the  private  sector  and  lack  of
competitive markets, the Government was compelled to cover up for any shortcomings leading
to  substantial  employment  creation  in  the  public  sector,  stringent  labor  laws,  expensive  social
programs, and unsustainable fiscal costs.

17.
Aside from bloating the bureaucracy, the immediate impact of Government policy was to
discourage domestic and foreign investments, dampen exports, and repress the financial sector.
Heavy  Government  intervention  and  a  highly  regulated  economy  also  spawned  gross
inefficiencies in the conduct of business activity.

Poor economic performance and macroeconomic imbalances that followed prompted the

wage  premium  in  protected  markets  (labor  and  tariff)  and  in  the  public  sector,  vis-à-vis  the
informal markets. This has created a large pool of educated and activist youths unwilling to take
up jobs in the informal, unprotected sectors, and waiting for jobs in the protected markets and
the public sector. This job search can be for extended periods.

43.
Nonetheless,  the  TEWA  was  introduced  to  stave  off  the  adverse  impact  of  import
restrictions  and  foreign  exchange  shortage  of  the  early  1970s  by  extending  state  control  over
retrenchments and expected layoffs in the private sector. The TEWA was viewed as a provision
of social protection to employees and has played an important role in preventing social unrest
resulting from mass layoffs.

Private sector entrepreneurs, employers federations, and local economists agree on the
44.
TEWA’s  negative  effects  on  investment  in  labor.  In  a  bid  to  arrest  the  widespread  evasion  of
labor laws, and the consequent trade union activism, which often led to violent confrontations,
the  1995  National  Workers’  Charter  was  formulated  with  the  participation  of  employers,
business  representatives,  and  trade  unions.  The  Government  agreed  to  prepare  a  code  of
industrial  harmony  defining  the  responsibilities  of  labor  and  employers,  and  to  provide  the
legislative  underpinning  to  the  Charter,  an  Employment  and  Industrial  Relations  Act.  The  first
draft of the act in 1996, prepared principally by the Ministry of Labor, met with severe resistance
from the business community for not meeting its concerns. Subsequently, the President of Sri
Lanka  appointed  a  task  force  on  employment  with  representatives  from  employers,  the  trade
unions and the Ministry of Labor. The task force advocated a phased relaxation of the TEWA.
The  task  force  proposed  the  introduction  of  a  scheme  to  determine  a  uniform  formula  for
establishing  compensation  for  involuntary  termination  that  would  be  acceptable  to  employers
and employees. However, the revised 1998 draft, issued by the Ministry of Labor, contained few
of the recommendations of the task force; employers subsequently boycotted the proceedings.
The issue was brought before the Prime Minister. A Presidential task force, constituted to revisit

 11

the issues, has submitted its recommendations. In separate meetings with employers and labor
unions, the current version appears to be more satisfactory to both groups, as it accommodates
many  of  their  recommendations.  Nonetheless,  the  labor  unions,  while  agreeing  in  principle  to
proposed reforms, wanted to directly participate in determining any uniform criteria and formula
for compensation of involuntary termination.

45. World Bank estimates place one fifth of the labor force, excluding those in nonregulated
sectors (such as the self-employed and those operating in the export processing zones) and in
plantation agriculture and the public enterprises, as falling under the current labor regulations. In
1999, Sri Lanka had a total workforce of 6.6 million, of which 6.1 million were employed. Of the
total employment, 14 percent were in the public sector, 44 percent in the private sector, and the
balance in the informal sector.  Private firms make significant contributions to GDP, and based
on  the  World  Bank’s  PSA  survey  ranked  labor  regulation  as  one  of  the  highest  constraints  to
business operations, expansion or diversification.

46.
Unemployment  in  Sri  Lanka  remains  a  significant  problem  for  the  country.  The
unemployment  rate  declined  from  an  average  of  more  than  13  percent  in  the  first  half  of  the
1990s  to  8.8  percent  in  1999.  Studies  indicate  that  labor  market  rigidities  and  labor  market
segmentation  are  the  major  causes  of  high  unemployment,  and  pose  a  serious  constraint  to
private sector development.

5. 

Access to Finance

47.
For  the  private  sector  to  participate  actively  in  economic  activities,  it  should  have
adequate access to finance at appropriate rates and terms. The private sector faces difficulties
accessing finance in Sri Lanka due mainly to substantial crowding out arising from Government
preemption of funds from the system, high cost of borrowing, scarcity of long-term funds, and an
underdeveloped  capital  market.  Consequently,  the  Colombo  Stock  Exchange  (CSE)  findings
show that the fund requirements of private companies are to a large extent met internally, then
from development finance institutions, and finally from commercial banks.

48.
Government  preemption  of  funds  from  the  financial  system  stems  from  its  large
borrowing requirements caused by its historically large budget deficits. Total Government debt
is about 95 percent of GDP and has grown in inflation-adjusted terms by 5 percent on average
since  1994.  Reliance  on  domestic  funding  sources  has  increased  in  recent  years,  with  a
consequent reduction in the share of foreign borrowing. In 1999, the share of foreign borrowing
by  the  Government,  as  a  percentage  of  GDP,  was  approximately  46  percent,  domestic
borrowing  comprised  49  percent.  Foreign  debt  has  been  higher  on  average  since  1994.  The
Government uses different instruments to borrow from the domestic market. Rupee loans, which
are  fixed-rate,  fixed-term  nonnegotiable  instruments,  constitute  a  large  portion  of  domestic
Government debt. Rupee loans are issued at administratively determined rates that are below
market rates and therefore distortionary. The maturity of a rupee loan is typically from 2 to 10
years,  although  it  may  extend  up  to  30  years.  The  bulk  of  such  loans  are  held  by  the
Employees’  Provident  Fund  (EPF)  and  the  Employees’  Trust  Fund  (ETF);  Government-
administered provident funds for private and public enterprises; and the National Savings Bank
(NSB), a Government-owned specialized financial institution.

The  other  major  instrument  is  the  Treasury  bill  (T-bill),  which  is  auctioned  through  the
49.
Central  Bank  of  Sri  Lanka  (CBSL).  T-bills  comprise  about  half  of  the  total  rupee  loans
outstanding.  T-bill  maturities  range  from  three  months  to  one  year.  Prior  to  1983,  CBSL  held
practically the entire issue of T-bills. However, as T-bill rates became market related, the share
held by CBSL declined to about 20 percent at the end of 1999. The major portion is now held by

 12

nonbank financial institutions and the public. The first issue of Treasury bonds with a two-year
maturity  was  made  in  1997.  Since  then,  maturities  have  lengthened;  the  most  recent  issue  in
September  1999  at  six  years.  However,  Treasury  bonds  still  comprise  a  small  portion  of  total
outstanding  Government  securities  at  about  19  percent  in  1999,  up  from  11  percent  in  1998
(Supplementary Appendix A lists outstanding Government securities and borrowings). The three
Government banks, NSB, Bank of Ceylon (BOC), and People’s Bank (PB), which act as primary
dealers in Government securities, including EPF and ETF, dominate the T-bill auctions (with an
estimated share of over 50 percent in 1999). Government preemption of funds ranges from as
much as close to 98 percent for the EPF, approximately 70 percent for ETF, over 80 percent for
NSB, 30-50 percent for the Government-owned insurance companies, and 30-35 percent for the
state  commercial  banks.  Along  with  the  relatively  high  rates  of  inflation,  interest  rates  have
therefore remained at high levels due to substantial Government borrowing from the domestic
financial market.

50.
The  two  state  banks,  BOC  and  PB,  despite  the  growth  in  market  share  of  private
commercial  banks  in  recent  years,  still  dominate  the  banking  system  in  Sri  Lanka,  accounting
for  slightly  over  50  percent  of  deposits  and  loans.  While  only  30  to  35  percent  of  loans  by
Government  commercial  banks  are  directed  credits,  such  loans  account  for  the  bulk  of  their
nonperforming portfolio. Based on official data, the ratio of nonperforming loans to total loans of
the  two  state  banks  was  close  to  20  percent  at  the  end  of  1998.  However,  according  to  a
diagnostic  review  by  international  auditors  commissioned  by  the  World  Bank  in  1998  at  the
request  of  the  Government,  and  based  on  international  standards  for  classification  and
provisioning  as  of  September  1998,  only  26  percent  of  the  loan  portfolio  of  PB  was  fully
performing  and  only  40  percent  in  the  case  of  BOC.  Add  this  to  the  high  level  of  staff  costs20
interest spreads of these banks are bound to rise contributing to the already high cost of funds
of  borrowers.  Current  spreads  range  from  about  6  to  9  percent.  Because  of  the  low  level  of
competition,  the  private  sector  banks  take  advantage  of  the  high  costs  of  operations  of  the
dominant state banks and charge similarly high rates of interest to their borrowers.

51.
NSB raises funds from the public through time and savings deposits and invests mainly
in  Government  securities.  NSB  has  about  12  million  deposit  accounts  that  are  transacted
through 100 branch offices and 4,100 post and subpost offices, with a total of 2,800 employees.
Total deposits of NSB increased from SLRs60 billion in 1995 to SLRs93 billion ($1.2 billion) in
1999. All deposits at NSB are guaranteed by the Government.

52.
According to the NSB (Amended) Act in 1995, NSB must invest at least 60 percent of its
deposits  in  Government  or  Government-guaranteed  securities.  Nonetheless,  claims  on
Government  and Government-guaranteed securities was over 80 percent in 1998. Historically,
NSB has paid deposit rates higher than the private banks.

53.
EPF,  the  largest  provident  fund  administered  by  the  Government  with  approximately  8
million  accounts,  of  which  1.9  million  accounts  are  active,  is  presently  the  largest  tax-paying
institution  in  Sri  Lanka,  holds  about  40  percent  of  domestic  Government  debt,  EPF  reported
total assets of SLRs186 billion ($2.5 billion) at the end of 1999. CBSL’s Monetary Board acts as
the  EPF’s  board;  this  creates  a  conflict  of  interest  as  CBSL  is  also  responsible  for  the  sale  of
Government issues. ETF, on the other hand, had investments in Government issues of about 70
percent  of  total  assets  at  the  end  of  1999.  ETF  has  about  30  percent  invested  in  private
corporate  securities,  of  which  about  10  percent  are  in  shares  of  stock.  However,  ETF  equity
investments  have  fared  badly.  Certain  investments  may  have  been  made  for  other  than

54.
Eight  insurance  companies  operate  in  Sri  Lanka:  two  are  state  owned:  Sri  Lanka
Insurance  Corporation  Ltd  (SLIC)  and  National  Insurance  Corporation  Ltd  (NIC).  The  two
companies were incorporated as public limited companies in 1993. Up to 1986, both SLIC and

percent of the life insurance market measured in terms of gross written premium in 1999. SLIC,
with total gross written premium of SLRs2.0 billion, is about 14 times the size of NIC in terms of
business  volume.  Insurance  companies  are  required  to  invest  in  Government  securities:  up  to
50 percent for life insurance and 30 percent for nonlife insurance companies. Public enterprises
are  required  to  insure  their  risks  with  either  NIC  or  SLIC  as  prescribed  by  Public  Enterprise
Circular  No.  94  of  1994.  The  private  insurance  companies  are  also  required  to  provide  a  15
percent reinsurance cession to NIC. The Exchange Control Act 1992 included a limit on foreign
investment in insurance companies of up to 40 percent. However, the limitation apparently did
not  extend  to  investments  using  holding  companies.  Consequently,  in  May  1998,  the  Zurich
Group was able to acquire 80 percent of CTC Eagle Insurance Co.

Investment funds are institutional investors in Sri Lanka. ADB assisted the establishment
55.
of  the  first  unit  trust  (mutual  fund)  in  Sri  Lanka  sponsored  by  the  DFCC  Bank  (formerly  the
Development  Finance  Corporation  of  Ceylon).22  Currently,  12  unit  trusts23  and  five  closed-end
investment funds are listed on the CSE. Two closed-end country funds were established in 1993
and  1994.  The  first  unit  trusts  were  balanced  growth  funds,  and  were  heavily  into  equities.
Consequently  their  performance  reflect  the  almost  continuous  downtrend  in  the  stock  market
since 1992. The investment funds have reported a total net asset value of SLRs2.4 billion ($31

income  instruments.  These  include  corporate  debentures,  T-bills,  and  Treasury  bonds,
commercial papers, repurchase agreements, and bank deposits.

58.
On  the  supply  side,  the  CSE  estimates  that  the  cost  of  equity  funds  is  about  17-21
percent;  other  market  players  believe  it  is  higher.  This  compares  with  the  cost  of  bank
borrowings of about 13 to 18 percent, which is also tax deductible. Lenient credit requirements,
particularly  by  the  state  banks,  make  borrowing  even  more  attractive.  Moreover,  issuers  are
reluctant to disclose information about their businesses and wish to maintain control.

The  corporate  debt  market  has  remained  thin  with  a  limited  number  of  issues.  Large,
59.
high  net  worth,  public  limited  liability  companies  raise  short-term  funds  by  issuing  commercial
papers and, to a limited extent, medium-term funds by issuing debentures. Factors that inhibit
the  faster  growth  of  a  market  for  debt  securities  include  the  absence  of  an  acceptable
benchmark for pricing corporate debt, market uncertainty, and lack of a liquid secondary market
for securities. The need for a credit-rating agency has been filled by Duff & Phelps Credit Rating
Lanka  Ltd,  which  became  operational  in  October  1999.  By  the  end  of  1999,  market
capitalization  of  listed  debentures  amounted  to  SLRs4.6  billion  against  SLRs3.7  billion  at  the
end of 1998.

60. Weak market regulation contributes to the low level of confidence and market weakness.
Areas  such  as  securities  underwriting,  investment  management,  and  commercial  paper
dealership are unregulated. Unlisted securities, which are traded off the exchange, are virtually
unregulated  as  under  the  prevailing  law  they  do  not  fall  within  the  jurisdiction  of  the  SEC.
Moreover, the SEC’s scope of authority to enforce market regulations is limited to investigation
and bringing suit before the courts.

61.

to  be  the  major  sources  of  long-term  finance,  accounting  for  around  30  percent  of  market

sources.26  In  the  domestic  market,  both  DFCC  Bank  and  NDB  have  been  able  to  raise  small

Government Objectives and Strategy

15

62.
The Government’s vision for the medium term is to achieve an economic growth rate of
7  to  8  percent  and  raise  per  capita  annual  income  from  slightly  above  SLRs65,000  ($837)  to
SLRs175,000  ($2,240)  by  2010.  The  Government  is  also  committed  to  raising  the  share  of
income of the poor from the current 4 percent to 15 percent by 2010. Considering the average
growth  rate  of  5.2  percent  achieved  in  the  past  10  years,  both  targets,  are  regarded  as
ambitious  and  highly  optimistic  for  the  country  in  general  and  for  the  poor  in  particular.  To
achieve  these  ambitious  targets,  the  cornerstone  of  the  Government’s  economic  strategy  is
private  sector-led  development.  A  private  sector-led  development  strategy  could  provide  the
necessary  momentum  that  could  lift  economic  growth  rates  and  reduce  poverty  to  the  targets
that the Government is aiming for.

63.
The  Government’s  fiscal  policy  is  to  be  aligned  to  support  this  strategy  and  will  aim  to
increase  public  savings,  contain  the  budget  deficit,  reduce  domestic  borrowing,  and  thereby
release more resources to be productively used by the private sector. The budget deficit is to be
reduced from 7.5 percent in 1999, to 4 percent in the medium term, and 3 percent by 2010. The
Government  will  (i)  liberalize  the  financial  sector  by  opening  it  up  to  foreign  investments  and
enhance access to new products and technologies, (ii) modernize the country’s infrastructure to
improve  services  required  by  the  private  sector,  and  (iii)  facilitate  private  sector  entry  into
infrastructure  development.  In  parallel,  the  Government  is  aiming  to  improve  public  sector
efficiency,  and  Government  expenditure  control  and  management;  introduce  a  performance-
based  salary  system;  reformulate 
the  pension  system;  and  undertake  organizational
improvements  in  key  agencies.  Structural  weaknesses  will  continue  to  be  addressed  while
maintaining the present levels of human development.

Sri Lanka hopes to fully exploit its locational advantage and establish itself as a regional

A. 

Rationale

Despite  the  civil  conflict,  Sri  Lanka’s  GDP  has  managed  to  grow  over  the  last  two
72.
decades  by  an  average  annual  rate  of  above  5  percent.  The  opening  up  of  the  Sri  Lankan
economy  in  1977  and  the  liberalization  of  trade  and  industry  in  1989  largely  account  for  this
growth. The economy has responded positively to Government initiatives to reform.

73.
However, to attain growth of 7-8 percent, as targetted by the Government as its goal for
the  medium  term,  the  country  must  aim  for  intensive  growth  anchored  upon  improved
efficiencies and greater productivity. This can only be achieved by a robust and dynamic private
sector operating within a properly regulated, stable, competitive, and efficient market system.31
Only sustained growth can lower unemployment and reduce poverty.

74.
Sri  Lanka  has  failed  to  fully  capitalize  on  earlier  reforms  liberalizing  the  trade  and
industrial  environment,  as  market  impediments  have  continued  to  constrain  private  sector
activity.  These  impediments  include  the  large  and  inefficient  public  enterprise  sector,  lack  of
competitive  markets  due  to  deficiencies  in  the  policy  framework  and  weak  incentive  structure,
labor market rigidities, and limited access to finance.

B. 

Objective and Scope

75.
The  objective  of  the  PSDP  is  to  facilitate  private  sector  participation  in  the  Sri  Lankan
economy  by  supporting  reforms  to  promote  efficiency  and  productivity  essential  for  higher
economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction.  ADB  assistance  will  aim  to  help  Sri  Lanka  (i)
consolidate and build upon the gains already achieved with earlier reforms, and (ii) move to a
higher and sustainable growth regime with the private sector as the prime mover of economic
growth.

76.
To achieve this objective, constraints that prevent the private sector from realizing its full
potential must be eliminated, and the market environment enhanced to promote competition and
thereby generate higher levels of savings and investments, and raise efficiency and productivity.
Subprogram  I  of  the  PSDP  seeks  to  develop  the  enabling  environment  for  private  sector
participation,  strengthen  regulatory  and  institutional  capacity  to  facilitate  and  oversee  private
sector  activity  and  market  operations,  improve  the  public-private  interface,  and  prepare  the
groundwork  for  sector  liberalization.  Subprogram  II  of  the  PSDP  will  aim  to  liberalize  the
infrastructure  and  other  sectors  that  remain  under  closed  state  ownership  and  control.  Thus,
independent regulatory authorities for water supply, power, and ports will be set up. In parallel,
public  infrastructure  institutions  will  be  restructured,  unbundled,  and  corporatized.  In  the
financial  sector,  the  state  banks  will  also  start  raising  capital  from  private  sources  as  the
Government  ceases  funding  for  them.  Other  reform  actions  will  update,  modify  or  complete
reforms  initiated  earlier.  Thus,  competition  policy  and  consumer  protection  (paras.  36  and  37)
are  to  be  reinforced  to  incorporate  best  practices  and  issues  that  arise  from  the  Sri  Lankan
experience. After a proposed ADB study, tax incentives will be rationalized to promote domestic
competition. A study of a formal social security system to institutionalize social protection will be
conducted.  Government  guarantees  on  deposits  will  be  eliminated,  and  a  deposit  insurance
scheme  for  small  depositors  will  be  established.  Reform  of  old-age  pensions  and  provident

Competition Policy and Consumer Protection

89.
Privatization  and  liberalization  in  Sri  Lanka  have  not  been  anchored  appropriately  on
effective regulatory frameworks and a clear competition policy. For the country to benefit from
greater private sector activity, it must foster competition to enhance efficiency, while regulating
private  sector  activity  to  ensure  that  investor  and  consumer  rights  are  adequately  protected.
This is of particular concern because existing Government monopolies are being transferred to
the private sector, especially in the various infrastructure sectors. Privatization of the gas sector
and divestment of SriLankan Airlines in civil aviation are examples. Moreover, in many respects,
the economy is dominated by a relatively small number of players, e.g., in plantation agriculture,
hotel industry, and banking.

TEWA has effectively served as the social safety net for workers and it has passed on
96.
the  burden  to  employers.  To  correct  this  anomaly,  the  PSDP  supports  establishing  a  social
safety  net  for  workers,  and  in  the  short  run,  assisting  with  job  counseling,  placement,  and
retraining  of  displaced  workers.  One  option  is  to  integrate  the  proposed  social  safety  net  with
the  Skills  Development  Fund  Limited  (SDFL)  which  was  set  up  with  an  SLRs100  million
investment by the Government in 1999. Counterpart investments of SLRs1 million have already
been committed to SDFL by the Employers Federation of Ceylon. Other private investors are to
be  invited  to  participate.  The  investment  income  from  the  contributed  funds  will  be  utilized  for
the operation of SDFL. The main activities of SDFL include providing training needs assessment
to  employees  and  designing  training  programs  to  suit  their  needs;  organizing  and  conducting
training  programs  at  state  and  enterprise  levels,  including  retraining  and  skills  upgrading,  to
develop  a  highly  skilled  workforce;  maintaining  computer  databases  and  web  servers  for  job-
related information; and providing linkages between training institutions and the private sector.
The  principal  targets  of  SDFL  are  entry-level  employees  and  employees  already  in  the
workforce.  A  pilot  program 
funded  by  United  Nations  Development  Programme  and
International Labour Organisation demonstrated the usefulness of SDFL to employees. Several
training  programs  were  undertaken  ranging  from  basic  engineering  technology  skills  transfer
programs  for  operational  and  supervisory  employees  to  managerial  skills  development
programs  targeting  middle  and  junior  executives  from  the  private  sector.  About  350  persons
were  trained;  employers  covered  the  costs.  The  social  safety  net  could  be  incorporated  with
SDFL  by  simply  expanding  the  SDFL’s  scope  of  operations  to  include  displaced  workers,  and
job  counseling  and  placement.  Counterpart  funds  from  the  PSDP  loans  could  be  utilized  as
additional capital; other sources, including the private sector, may also be tapped. Moreover, the
social  safety  net  could  operate  on  a  cost  recovery  basis  by  charging  appropriate  fees  for
workers  that  find  suitable  employment,  e.g.,  one-month  salary,  which  is  the  practice  of  some
private  employment  agencies.  To  insulate  it  from  outside  interference,  management  can  be
outsourced  to  a  private  sector  agency  using  a  performance  contract,  appropriate  selection
qualification criteria, and transparent, competitive bidding. The Government has requested ADB
assistance in designing the proposed social safety net.

97.
Over the longer term, only a formal social security system that provides specific welfare
benefits  and  insurance  for  displaced  workers  can  assuage  the  uncertainty  and    apprehension
over  job  loss.  The  Government  should  seriously  consider  developing  a  comprehensive  but
sustainable social security system.

The lack of effective labor market mechanisms and weak capacity of the present system
98.
to  settle  labor  disputes  are  root  causes  of  labor  agitation.  Currently,  labor  disputes  are
submitted  to  the  Ministry  of  Labor  for  conciliation.  Conciliation  is  undertaken  by  labor  officials,
who  are  usually  few  in  number  and  undertrained.  When  conciliation  fails,  the  labor  dispute  is
submitted  for  arbitration.  A  panel  of  arbitrators,  outside  the  Ministry  of  Labor,  are  typically
appointed  for  a  fixed  period.  Under  the  Industrial  Disputes  Act,  recourse  is  through  the  labor
tribunals,  which  are  part  of  the  Ministry  of  Justice.  The  tribunals  are  clogged  with  labor  cases
awaiting  resolution.  Undue  concentration  is  focused  on  the  legal  aspects  of  labor  cases,
particularly, in looking for precedents, rather than for ways of settling the dispute. The result is
that labor cases take an inordinate amount of time.

99.
Consequently,  to  facilitate  the  settlement  of  labor  disputes  and  to  promote  industrial
harmony, the PSDP will strengthen the process of dispute resolution. The Ministry of Labor will

 25

strengthen the current system of arbitration by defining the bases for selection of the panel of
arbitrators  in  accordance  with  objective  qualification  criteria  under  appropriate  regulation,
requiring appointed arbitrators to undergo basic training in labor arbitration.

100. An initiative currently under way, spearheaded by the Employers’ Federation of Ceylon,
is using mediation to settle labor disputes. Under the International Executive Service Corps and
USAID  Technology  Initiative  for  the  Private  Sector,  a  voluntary  executive  has  conducted
mediation workshops to train mediators for, and obtain commitment for mediation from, private
companies  with  the  participation  of  labor  unions.  As  a  result,  the  Employment  Mediation
Services Centre was set up to resolve employment related disputes. Any employee or union, on
behalf  of  a  member  or  employer,  may  request  mediation  to  resolve  a  dispute  or  impending
dispute to be conducted by trained mediators. The Ministry of Justice has attained a relatively
high  degree  of  success  in  achieving  dispute  settlements  in  civil  cases  through  mediation,  and
has  over  5,000  mediators  across  the  country.  To  support  the  process,  TA  is  to  be  provided
under the PSDP to build mediation capacity at the Employment Mediation Services Centre and
train trainers for labor conciliation and arbitration at the Ministry of Labor.

5. 

Access to Finance

101.
Improved access to financing and capital by the private sector depends largely upon the
success  of  the  fiscal  consolidation  effort  by  the  Government  and  reduction  of  crowding  out
effects  of  Government  borrowings  in  the  market,  the  increased  efficiency  of  financial
intermediation in Sri Lanka, and development of the domestic capital market.

102. While  remaining  relatively  high,  the  budget  deficit  was  contained  to  7.5  percent  45  in
1999 from a peak of 10.1 in the last five years (Supplementary Appendix G shows Sri Lanka’s
fiscal  accounts).  Public  dissaving  (the  difference  between  Government  revenues  and  current
expenditures,  representing  the  deficit  financing  required  by  the  Government,  which  effectively
reduces savings in the system available to the private sector) has been reduced from a high of
3.9 percent to 1.0 percent over the same period (Supplementary Appendix H presents savings
and  investments  information  for  1995-1999).  In  its  recent  budget  pronouncement,  the
Government committed to continue its fiscal consolidation effort and reduce the fiscal deficit to
5.0 percent by 2002. As part of its medium-term strategy, the Government is limiting domestic
borrowings to release more resources for productive use by the private sector.

103. As  the  Government  reduces  its  public  borrowings,  it  can  assuage  the  crowding  out  of
private  sector  borrowers  by  eliminating  distortions  in  the  pricing  of  Government  issues  and
promoting  competition  in  the  funds  market.  The  Government  intends  to  progressively  replace
nonmarketable  rupee  loans  with  Treasury  bonds.  However  this  can  be  achieved  only  by
accelerating  the  development  of  the  Government  securities  market  (para.  49).  In  1992,  the
Government  appointed  11  accredited  primary  dealers  in  Government  securities.  This  was
increased  to  18  in  1997.  The  primary  dealers  are  provided  privileged  access  to  auctions  of
Government  securities  in  return  for  making  markets  for  these  securities.  To  strengthen  the
system,  CBSL  has  required  that  all  primary  dealers  be  established  as  separate  dedicated
entities with capitalization of SLRs150 million. Moreover, the present over-the-telephone market
is to be replaced by the formal listing and trading of Government securities at the CSE. With the
higher  required  capitalization,  the  number  of  primary  dealers  was  reduced  to  8.  To  facilitate
secondary  market  trading,  the  Government  is  preparing  to  automate  the  present  system,

104. However, while the major buyers of Government debt instruments are also Government-
owned and controlled financial institutions, the process is not likely to be viewed as being even

105.
The two large state commercial banks, BOC and PB, will be restructured according to a
plan  prepared  by  external  consultants47  and  approved  by  the  Government.  As  a  first  step,  the
Government  will  institutionalize  a  corporate  governance  framework  in  both  BOC  and  PB  to
ensure  the  autonomy  of  the  boards  of  directors  and  management  of  both  state  banks  and
mechanisms  for  effective  enforcement.  Management  is  now  being  gradually  transferred  to
private  individuals.  In  the  case  of  BOC,  a  chief  financial  officer  (CFO)  is  being  recruited
internationally,  with  an  advertisement  in  a  major  international  publication.  This  was  a  major
concession by the labor union. The chief financial officer will be reporting to the chairperson in
parallel  with  the  chief  operating  officer.  In  the  case  of  PB,  all  principal  officers  are  now  to  be
recruited internationally, starting with the chief executive officer .

The operations of both banks will be rationalized, to ensure that appropriate competition
106.
policy is followed. The restructuring plan will (i) define measures for restoring and strengthening
the  soundness  of  both  banks  and  for  improving  their  operational  efficiencies;  (ii)  map  out
strategic  and  corporate  business  plans  defining  their  strategic  objectives;  (iii)  lay  out  a
performance and accountability framework; a system of credit and recovery management; and a
program  for  cost  reduction,  productivity  improvement,  and  branch  rationalization;  and  (iv)
identify  measures  for  staffing  and  deployment,48  and  recommendations  for  improving  human
resource  policies  and  practices.  The  Government  will  provide  ADB  with  a  timebound
monitorable action plan to undertake restructuring of BOC and PB, substantially as described.
Subsequently, a financial plan will be prepared for both BOC and PB, and the Government will
consider  the  feasibility  of  allowing  private  sector  entry  into  BOC  by  offering  employee  stock
options  and  possible  listing  through  the  CSE.  A  majority  of  BOC  employees  are  scheduled  to
reach  retirement  age  starting  in  2003.  After  the  recruitment  of  private  management,  PB’s  role
will be redefined to emphasize operations in areas not otherwise served by the private sector.
Any attempt at outright privatization is likely to lead to confrontation that could derail the reform
process based on past experience. The Government has agreed that it will adopt a hard budget
for both state banks after completing the restructuring.

107.

Government  can  raise  finance  on  short  notice  and  at  administered  market  rates:  NSB  can  fix
deposit rates while the Government can influence the rates at which it borrows from NSB. The

109.
For  contractual  savings,  the  Government  has  committed  to  liberalize  the  insurance
industry and investments of the provident fund schemes, EPF and ETF under the PSDP. The
Regulation  of  Insurance  Industry  Act  was  passed  by  Parliament.  The  act  reduces  the
requirement for mandated investment in Government securities from 50  percent  to  30  percent
for  life  insurance  companies,  and  from  30  to  20  percent  for  non-life  insurance  companies;
eliminates the mandatory reinsurance cession to NIC; allows insurance companies to reinsure
with international reinsurers without the need for prior Government approval; and permits up to

legislation  and  regulations,  designing  an  appropriate  regulatory  framework,  identifying  the
requirements  and  needs  of  the  proposed  regulatory  agency,  and  preparing  a  detailed  action
plan for its establishment. ADB has been asked to assist the operationalization of the regulatory
authority.

110.
For  the  pension  and  provident  funds,  the  Government  will  need  to  adopt  a
comprehensive  strategy  to  restructure  the  present  system,  and  formulate  an  overall  plan  of
reform to strengthen fund management in order to improve fund yields, diversify investments to
include private securities, extend coverage, strengthen administration, and rationalize taxation.
Among  the  options  to  be  considered  are  (i)  the  privatization  of  fund  management  that  can  be
entrusted to outside fund managers through an appropriate accreditation system; (ii) the extent
of liberalization to which funds may invest in private securities and the investment grade limits
for  such  investments;  (iii)  the  possibility  of  investing  funds  in  the  international  equity  and  debt
markets  in  view  of  limited  investment  opportunities  in  the  domestic  market;  (iv)  approaches  to
widen coverage to provide access to the poor; and (v) the possibility of centralizing collections
and  disbursements  as  well  as  accounting  for  EPF  and  ETF  to  improve  efficiency  of
administration. The development finance institutions have large requirements that are currently
being  sourced  principally  from  multilateral  financing  agencies.  Contractual  savings  could
appropriately  be  used  to  finance  part  of  the  long-term  requirement  for  development  projects
subject to appropriate risk mitigation. As a first step, a superannuation benefits funds regulatory
commission  bill  is  under  preparation  and  will  be  introduced  in  Parliament.  The  regulatory

commission,49 once formed, will then undertake reform of the present system. ADB assistance
has been requested to prepare the reform plan. This will be coordinated with ongoing support
from  the World Bank. The  World  Bank has provided substantial support to the Government in
this area, including an investment management study for EPF, TA for the regulatory reform of
the private provident funds, training at a pension workshop at Harvard University, and a pension

111.
To  promote  stability  in  the  securities  markets,  governance  will  be  improved  with  the
immediate introduction of amendments to the SEC Act to include broadening SEC’s jurisdiction
to cover other market players, such as, securities underwriters, and investment managers, and
increasing its investigative powers. Further strengthening of existing legislation will however be
needed as the legislation about to be presented to Parliament does not address SEC’s lack of
jurisdiction over financial advisers, commercial paper issuance and trading, use of repurchase
agreements, and unlisted securities. Moreover, SEC’s enforcement powers must be enhanced
for the watchdog agency to effectively discharge its functions. Under the present arrangement,
SEC  can  only  investigate  and  prosecute  through  the  regular  courts.  It  cannot  penalize  nor

must  be  clearly  demarcated  to  ensure  proper  coordination  of  financial  market  regulation  and
supervision. For example, the Government is currently moving to bring merchant banks under
the CBSL supervision, not SEC supervision.

112. Measures to broaden and deepen the capital market have been undertaken by opening
up  the  industry  to  foreign  participation,  such  as,  the  mutual  funds  and  securities  brokerage

regulation  for  the  introduction  of  new  instruments  and  mechanisms  such  as  derivatives  for

Social and Environmental Issues

1. 

Social Impact

The social impact of privatization in Sri Lanka is mitigated through voluntary retirement
113.
schemes  promoted  at  the  preprivatization  stage.  These  schemes  have  been  offered  to  all
employees but are not subject to any fixed formula and vary depending on negotiations with the
labor  unions.  The  PERC  and  the  labor  commissioner  are  believed  to  be  involved  in  these
settlements. Average retrenchment compensation is estimated to have gone up from 45 to 53
months’ salary, excluding amounts payable under welfare benefit schemes and the accelerated
withdrawal  of  EPF  benefits  from  1991  to  1997.  Without  the  threat  of  dismissal,  voluntary
retirement  costs  have  increased.  As  a  matter  of  policy,  the  Government  is  to  distribute  10
percent  of  the  outstanding  shares  of  its  corporatized  companies  to  employees  at  the  time  of
partial divestment or privatization. In practice, this varies from 3 to 10 percent depending upon
the relative value of the companies and the number of employees involved. In this regard, Sri
Lanka has one of the most generous schemes for promoting worker participation and ownership
in the world. Nonetheless, to ensure that due diligence is carried out for the voluntary retirement
of workers in public enterprises to be divested under the PSDP, plans for voluntary retirement
are required to be submitted to ADB prior to actual divestment.

VIII.  PROGRAM BENEFITS AND RISKS

A. 

Benefits

140.  There is broad consensus that the future development of Sri Lanka hinges on resolving
the civil conflict and attaining a higher growth regime. Only through higher and sustained growth
can  the  country  create  jobs,  raise  standards  of  living,  maintain  high  levels  of  human
development,  and  reduce  poverty.  However,  the  transition  to  a  higher  and  sustained  growth
regime  will  require  generating  more  savings  and  investments,  and  increasing  Sri  Lanka’s
competitiveness.51  This  can  only  be  delivered  by  a  responsive  and  dynamic  private  sector
operating within a stable and competitive market.

141.  The PSDP, which supports private sector development, will assist the Government meet
its  development  objectives.  It  will  encourage  greater  private  sector  activity,  facilitate  private
sector entry and participation, and open up areas of investment until now reserved for the public
sector. It will help eliminate market distortions that impede the growth of the private sector and
promote a policy environment that will enable a market to operate that is conducive to private

B. 

Risks

142.  The  most  significant  risk  is  the  continuing  civil  conflict  in  the  northeast  or  in  the  worst
case, the spread of the conflict. Under this scenario, reform will be difficult for the Government
to pursue and will likely delay reforms. Thus far, given the present level of the current conflict
and the limited military operation geographically, the country has been able to pursue its reform
programs  and  infrastructure  projects,  except  where  there  is  active  military  engagement.  The
Government is nonetheless taking concrete steps to seek a peaceful resolution of the conflict.
More power is being devolved to Tamil-majority regions, Norwegian assistance for negotiating a
peaceful settlement of the conflict has been mobilized, and relief and rehabilitation of affected
people,  for  which  ADB  assistance  has  been  sought,  is  being  addressed.  The  Government  is
committed to maintain current levels of social expenditures, in health and education.

143.  A  change  in  the  composition  of  Government  can  also  pose  a  risk  in  terms  of  a  policy
shift.  However,  it  is  not  likely  a  dramatic  change  in  policies  or  a  reversal  to  past  policies  will
occur. The previous change in Government did not significantly alter the broad macroeconomic
and market policy orientation. Moreover, there appears to be broad consensus and support for
current liberalization measures and a private sector-led strategy.

144.  Another  risk  is  lack  of  political  will  to  carry  out  the  reforms,  inasmuch  as  the  PSDP
covers  a  number  of  politically  sensitive  areas,  including,  labor  issues,  privatizations  of  public
enterprises,  and  restructuring  of  the  state  banks.  However,  the  Government  has  been
successful  in  overcoming  resistance  in  these  areas,  with  large  privatizations  in  industry  and
opening up of selected infrastructure sectors as well as divestments in plantations. Moreover, in
both  labor  and  restructuring  of  the  state  banks,  there  has  been  substantive  preparatory  work
undertaken, although consensus building is not easily achieved.

This  letter  refers  to  the  Government’s  request  for  assistance  from  the  Asian
Development  Bank  (ADB)  for  support  of  a  policy  reform  program  to  promote  private

A.

Development Objectives, Strategy and Plans

The  challenges  facing  Sri  Lanka  are,  on  the  main,  twofold,  to  seek  a  just  and
lasting  peace  in  the  country  and  to  raise  the  level  of  economic  growth  on  a  sustained
basis in order to meet the country’s development objectives.

The Government has waged a campaign seeking a speedy resolution of the civil
conflict,  on  one  hand,  through  domestic  and  international  isolation  of  the  terrorist
elements involved in the current conflict, and on the other, through persuasive measures
to  win  over  the  peaceful  majority  by  ensuring  equal  rights  for  all  communities  and
improved sharing of political power through constitutional change. The Government has
also sought bilateral assistance in seeking a mediated settlement  to  the  conflict.  Relief
and  rehabilitation  of  the  affected  population  is  being  addressed  and  in  this  regard,  an
emergency  loan  has  been  requested  from  the  ADB.  The  Government  is  committed  to
contain spending for defense outlays and protecting social expenditures, particularly for
health and education.

Sri  Lanka  has  performed  creditably  in  the  last  decade  growing  at  an  average
annual rate of over 5 percent. I say creditably because such growth was achieved during
a period of internal strife and external turmoil that witnessed the Mexican crisis, the ruble
crisis  in  Russia,  and  the  financial  meltdown  in  East  Asia.  The  macroeconomy  has
remained stable with inflation on the decline from a peak of about 16 percent in the last
five  years  to  below  5  percent  in  1999.  Interest  rates  have  consequently  fallen.  The
external  debt  burden  of  the  country  has  also  steadily  declined  since  1995  with  the
external debt to GDP ratio falling from over 70 percent five years ago to just above 57
per  cent  in  1999.    The  debt  service,  in  relation  to  the  country’s  exports,  although
minimally rising remains manageable at slightly above 15 percent.

Over  the  immediate  future,  the  outlook  remains  favorable  with  real  economic
growth expected to rise by 6 percent both in 2000 and  in 2001 with the overall recovery
in world trade. A dramatic improvement in the economic scenario is possible should the
current conflict be resolved.

However, the Government realizes that for the country to meet its development
objectives,  it  needs  to  transition  to  a  higher    growth  regime,  and  for  this  growth  to  be
sustained, it needs to mobilize larger amounts of resources, become more efficient in the
use  of  such  resources  and  to  raise  labor  productivity.  As  public  resources  can  only
finance  a  part  of  the  requirements  for  sustained  and  higher  growth,  to  boost  the
country’s competitiveness, would mean providing a greater role for the country’s private
sector  as  the  main  driver  of  the  economy  while  shifting  the  role  of    Government  from

 B.

The Program

Consequently,  the  Government  has,  with  ADB  assistance,  finalized  a  plan  of
action to promote private-sector led development as the key component of its medium-
term economic strategy.

The  results  of  earlier  reforms  have  indicated  that  Sri  Lanka’s  private  sector
responds positively to reforms. However, the country has failed to fully capitalize on past
reforms  liberalizing  the  trade  and  industry  sectors  due  to  market  distortions  and
imperfections  of  the  market  system  that  continue  to  constrain  private  sector  activity.
These  include  inefficiencies  in  the  large  public  enterprise  sector,  lack  of  competitive
markets due to deficiencies in the policy framework and  weak incentive structure, labor
market rigidities, and limited access to finance, particularly for long-term capital.

The Private Sector Development Program will thus address identified constraints
to  private sector activity and will have the following key objectives: (i) public enterprise
reform  and  continued  reduction  in  Government  ownership  and  control  of  public
enterprises engaged in commercial operations; (ii) develop the enabling environment for
private  sector  participation  in  infrastructure;  (iii)  enhance  the  market  system  by
promoting  fair  market  competition  and  the  appropriate  regulation  of  private  sector
activity; (iv) facilitate labor market mobility; and (v) improve access to funds.

(i) 

Public  enterprise  reform  and  reduction  of    Government  ownership  and
control over public enterprises engaged in commercial operations

The  Government  is  gradually  encouraging  private  sector  entry  and  participation
in  public  enterprises  engaged  in  commercial  operations  through  its  public  enterprise
reform  program.  The  Government  has  relinquished  ownership  and/or  control  over  82
companies since the early 1990’s. The current program calls for the sale of Government
shares both fully and partially in 42 more public enterprises.

To  complement  this  effort,  the  Government  will  also  seek  to  institutionalize
commercial  principles  into  the  operations  of  those  remaining  public  commercial
enterprises that are not yet ready to be taken over by the private sector and will undergo
restructuring. A corporate governance framework will be adopted and enforced for these
public enterprises to promote transparency and  efficiency.

However,  far  more  important  perhaps  is  the  change  in  policy  adopted  by  this
Government  to  pursue  a  redefined  role  that  focuses  on  the  sectors  where  market
mechanisms  do  not  as  yet  function  effectively  such  as  in  education,  health,  the
environment,  rural  and  small  sectors,  safety  nets  for  the  poor  and  social  and  cultural

(iv)

Labor market mobility

The  adverse  effects  of  an  inflexible  labor  market  are  well  known.  Present-day
labor laws need to be tailored to meet the demands of an open economy. Accordingly,
the Government has initiated the review of needed reforms in labor legislation under a
proposed Employment and Industrial Relations Act. Of special concern in this regard, is
the need to reach agreement on a standard formula and uniform criteria for involuntary
employee separation. A working committee is thus to be formed to take up much needed
labor  market  reforms  to  be  composed  of  representatives  from    the  labor  unions,
employers,  the  Government,  and  labor  experts.  The  Government  recognizes  the
importance of this process and that the quality of consultations will ultimately determine
the  durableness  of  the  reforms.  The  recommendation  of  this  working  committee  will
become the basis for amending existing legislation.

However, while voluntary or involuntary compensation will provide some relief to
workers,  it  does  not  assist  workers  find  alternative  gainful  employment.  Consequently,
under  the  Program,  a  social  safety  net  will  be  set  up  with  the  objective  of  providing
displaced workers with job counseling, job placement and retraining services. Over the
long-term,  a  social  security  system  that  will  provide  specific  welfare  benefits  and
insurance for displaced workers will be considered. The Government will weigh the costs
and benefits of such a system and its possible design and structure.

borrowings  from  the  state-owned  financial  institutions  to  the  issuance  of  Government

2.
Despite the favorable social indicators, about 17.5 million of the population reside

percent  in  the  urban  sector  based  on  the  higher  poverty  line,  largely  a  result  of
inadequate  basic  social  and  infrastructure  services.  The  findings  in  the  Framework  for
Poverty  Reduction  will  be  reinforced  by  the  ongoing  integrated  household  income  and
expenditure survey by the Department of Census and Statistics to be completed by the
end of 2000.

3.
Most  of  the  poor  are  concentrated  in  the  Central,  Uva,  Sabaragamuwa,  and

nonfarm  activities  has  been  restricted  by  major  infrastructure  deficiencies  especially
roads, electricity, irrigation, and communication facilities. Malnutrition among children is
also prevalent in these provinces. In six of the seven surveyed provinces (excluding the
Northern and Eastern provinces), and with considerable variation among the provinces,
about 60-75 percent of the population have no access to electricity, about 27-48 percent
have  no  access  to  safe  drinking  water  and  over  20-34  percent  lack  access  to  safe
sanitation.

8.
A set of stable and consistent macroeconomic policies underpins private sector-
led growth and development. It is aptly noted in the Government Framework for Poverty
Reduction  that  macroeconomic  policies  for  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction
would  consist  of  (i)  sound  fiscal  management,  (ii)  expansion  of  the  monetary  base

structural  policies  to  promote  private  sector  development  (e.g.,  continued  divestiture  of
Government  commercial  enterprises  and  establishment  of  a  corporate  governance
framework for state-owned enterprises), and (vi) labor market reforms to improve labor
market mobility. Severe macroeconomic instability acts like a regressive tax on the poor.
Instability  erodes  confidence,  which  then  reduces  the  amount  of  investment.  Lower
investment  reduces  employment  growth  and  leaves  many  poor  households  trapped  in
low-productivity  self-employment.  High  rates  of  inflation  erode  the  value  of  the  wages
